prompt.p: A 40-year-old man coming to your surgery complains of tiredness and lethargy.
On examination he has conjunctival and palmar crease pallor.
A full blood count reveals decreased haemoglobin and platelets, but a very raised white cell count. He is diagnosed with a leukaemia.
If the patient were to respond rapidly and potently to All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) therapy, what condition are they likely to be suffering from?

modalFeedback.p:
Option D (Acute promyelocytic leukaemia) is Correct. ATRA promotes their differentiation, reducing APML neoplastic potential.
Option A (Chronic myelogenous leukaemia) is Incorrect. Is chronic and so wouldn't respond acutely to any chemotherapy.
Option B (Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia) is Incorrect. This occurs mostly in children.
Option C (Hodgkin's disease) is Incorrect. This is a lymphoma, not leukaemia.
Option E (Chronic myelogenous leukaemia) is Incorrect. This is chronic and so wouldn't respond acutely to any chemotherapy.
